Award.AwardTitle: Investigations of 2- and 3- point Intrinsic Alignments of Galaxies (II, GI, III, GGI, GII) and their Isolation in Current and Future Lensing Surveys
Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to address intrinsic alignment systematics in weak lensing studies, which are used along with galaxy surveys to assess the large-scale mass distribution of the universe (including dark matter). The results will be important in the future for studies by the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST). Broader impacts of the work include training of a graduate student, engaging in research projects that incorporate women in physics and summer students from high schools, and workshop talks for high school teachers and general public talks on cosmology.

The work will addresses systematic errors that arise from a variety of intrinsic alignments in weak lensing studies. The aim is to develop and analyze 2-pt and 3-pt intrinsic alignment measures from theory, simulations, and from actual measurements from the CFHTLenS and VIPERS galaxy surveys.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Gravitational lensing is one of the most powerful astrophysical probes to constrain the properties and evolution of the universe, hence a number of important lensing surveys are ongoing or planned to start in the next few years, such as DES, LSST, Euclid and WFIRST. However, intrinsic alignments (IA) of galaxies act as a contaminant to the lensing signal and have been recognized as one of most serious systematic effects facing this probe. Intrinsic alignment signal must be extracted and removed from gravitational lensing to allow it to reach its full potential. The main achievements of this project were the maturation and implementation of a self-calibration extraction technique of IA, and its successful application to data from the Kilometer Degree Survey (KIDS-450).

IA can arise when physically close galaxies are aligned by the gravitational field of the matter surrounding them (known as II-type of correlations), or when a matter structure links the orientation of a galaxy close to it to the lensed image of a galaxy far behind it (known as GI-type). While II-type can be minimized by using galaxies in different redshift bins, this does not work for the GI-type since this occurs between galaxies at different redshifts and large separations.

It has been shown in the literature and confirmed in this investigation that if the IA contaminants are ignored, the determination of the dark energy equation of state from lensing is biased by 50% and the matter power spectrum amplitude is biased by up to 30%. Thus, it is important to isolate the IA signal. Furthermore, the extraction and understanding of galaxy alignments, which reflect the formation and evolution of galaxies in their environments, provides valuable information on structure formation.

There has been active work to search for methods to remove the GI-type and the self-calibration method has been recognized by the lensing community to work the best since it does not throw away part of the lensing signal. The method uses other correlations that can be extracted from the same survey to calculate and remove the IA signal. In this project, we also developed a variant of the self-calibration method that can be applied to both types of IA. We quantified the effects of self-calibration on cosmological parameter constraints from future gravitational lensing surveys in a theoretical setting exploring the effect of galaxy bias on the performance of the method. We also investigated the effect of IA on testing general relativity, cosmic acceleration and dark energy. We performed analytical calculations, code development and various testing to implement and mature the self-calibration method so it can be applied to real data.

Our application of the self-calibration to the KIDS-450 survey led to the first direct measurement of GI-type of IA in a pure photometric redshift survey. It opened up an important route to deal with the IA problem for ongoing and future lensing/clustering photometric surveys such as DES, LSST, Euclid, WFIRST and others.

The investigation had broader impacts at various levels. At the University of Texas at Dallas, it allowed the direct training of two dedicated PhD students in research and paper writing, as well as three other graduate and six undergraduate students involved in weekly group meetings and research discussions during the life of this project. These students include three undergraduate female students and a Hispanic graduate student. Four of the undergraduate students joined afterwards graduate programs. PI also integrated at UT-Dallas research results into astrophysics courses including a popular cosmology course.

PI and his students have been active members of the LSST-Dark Energy Science Collaboration (DESC) during this project. They disseminated the results via telecon discussions and talks at the DESC collaboration meetings. During this award, PI and his students gave talks at the AAS meetings and contributed to the organization of Texas Symposia on Relativistic Astrophysics. These activities reached the wide astrophysics community.

Finally, in order to reach even broader audiences during the conduction of the project, PI sponsored monthly meetings of the Texas Astronomy Society on the campus of UT-Dallas and gave a public lecture before it members. These meetings include typically 200 amateur astronomers with great interest in what is happening on the research front in astronomy and cosmology, including people with various ages ranging from high school students to senior retired individuals. PI also gave a general lecture on cosmology to the UT-Dallas Society of Physics Students, mainly undergraduate students from physics and other science majors. PI gave an interview at the KERA-NPR radio station in Dallas and an invited public lecture at South Methodist University in Dallas. PI gave a public lecture in front of a very broad audience at the Dallas Perot Museum of Sciences. This was at the opening night of the special exhibition Journey to Space. At each of these opportunities, PI presented and discussed results from this investigation.
